title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Turkey before 1 January 2017?
preds: Erdogan loves to hunt down Kurds and the Stadium bombings give him an excuse and prior to DT TAKING OFFICE would be prudent.
Down 15% due to passage of time.
Scaling down because January 1st is almost here.

Turkey, my country. I hope there will never be such a tragedy both in my country and anywhere in the world. I will be truly objective: Turkey lived an enormous unity after July 15, 2016 Failed Coup Attempt. However the politicians begin to split against the wishes of Turkish People, they couldn't keep this soul inside their policy. Turkey has lots of threats both at home and abroad. The exterior enemies are not countries but the global terrorist organizations, e. g. ISIS is a huge threat also for Turkey. PKK's been its enemies for over 30 years. FETO, led by cleric Fethullah Gulen (former-ally-then-enemy for the ruling party AKP), is also a matter of Turkish national security. But Turkey has become closer again with its former allies, Russia and Israel. If friendly and well-intended cooperation between those countries become much more strong, Turkey will continue to protect its current stable atmosphere. Yet I see an comparetively high per cent of chance for a bad incident until Christmas.

ISIS might choose turkey for attacks as they have been pushed out of Mosul. They probably try their best to respond Mosul offensive by attacks outside their territory for propaganda reason. Continuous Russian and Assad's attack on Aleppo could increase refugee flow from Syria to turkey which increases the chance of ISIS infiltration in turkey as well. However, the security will be tight as well.​
Down from 5% entered on 15 September, for passage of time

Troubling new developments this past week with the arrest of members of congress belonging to the second largest opposition party, the pro-Kurdish HDP.  The government accuses the HDP of "financing and supporting an armed Kurdish insurgency." 
Erdogan has also issued "emergency decrees extending the time detainees can be held without counsel and allowing foreigners to Thebe deported without a court order." Police raided the country’s oldest independent newspaper, Cumhuriyet, and arrested two mayors of the largest majority-Kurdish province, Diyarbakir. Meanwhile, HDP is boycotting parliament. Multiple cities report government interference in accessing Facebook, YouTube, Skype, Instagram, Twitter, and WhatsApp through ISP throttling.  Many newspapers are calling the Turkish government actions as an "all out war against the Kurds."   Sources:  
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-turkey-security-kurds-idUSKBN13109Y?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews&utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=Social&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Reuters%2FworldNews+%28Reuters+World+News%29 http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/11/04/erdogans-latest-crackdown-and-how-turkeys-chaos-plays-to-extremists-strengths/ We will have to watch these developments closely in the next couple of weeks.
There were a lot of killings, injury, imprisonment, etc during coup and subsequent state of emergency - numbers didn't rise to meet definition of "mass killing"

Casualties have been sparse since the State of Emergency was declared, and most conflict attributed to Turkey appears to be happening in Syria. It seems that Russia benefits from stability in Turkey and there exists some cooperation. Also, time window for the forecast is closing.

Need to watch conditions there - operations against Kurdish areas going on recently and sounds like stepping up today.  Mayor of Diyarbakir has been detained or arrested.  Saw something yesterday about destruction of tents where IDPs living - also targeting of Kurdish area.  Still low on this forecast because untangling deaths due to violence from deaths of civilians will to be difficult.
Fair number of deaths so far. Massive instability in Syria poses spillover threat in Turkey

If this question resolves with a "YES" will it make a difference?

For convenience: "We will consider a mass killing to have occurred when the deliberate actions of armed groups, including but not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias, result in the deaths of at least 1,000 noncombatant civilians targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less. A noncombatant civilian is any person who is not a current member of a formal or irregular military organization and who does not pose an immediate threat to the life, physical safety, or property of other people." Source http://www.earlywarningproject.com/definitions The death toll of the failed coup was 300  and some of them were not even noncombatant civilians.  It is hard to imagine that in the next 5 months there will be an incident in Turkey that will meet the terms of that definition.

(no change for now) I’ve resigned myself to NOT getting any further clarification from EWP on what constitutes a mass killing. (Consequently, I’ve not elected to join the more recent questions.) Looking at part of the EWP definitions, I’d like to offer an opinion about two points related to this phrase: “targeted as part of a specific group, over a period of one year or less” 1. I now believe (but wouldn’t be surprised if EWP made a clarification that contradicted this) that the period related to any specific question starts when the question is introduced and runs through the end of CY 2016. (I believe the other ideas that it either looks back in a running period of a year or is the whole calendar year are wrong.) 2. There are at least two interpretations of which group(s) are targeted. A narrow interpretation is that whatever government (“in” tribe) forces there are target only a specific subset of the population. Then there is a broader interpretation that any significant deaths that are not combat related or otherwise proscribed would count (in the sense that those targeted are “outsiders” in some sense). I lean now toward accepting either, but probably put less weight on the latter as I think about a particular situation.

Male citizens after serving their compulsory service are obligated to be recalled up to military service until they are 46 years of age. After males are recalled up, the Turkish parliament can declare that the state is in a critical condition which makes women from ages 18 to 42 are obligated to serve. As many of us here remember - compulsory service is a great homogenizer of ethnic groups. Should the ax fall only on one or two groups it will ripple into the population of the soldiers families and create a caste system beyond rank in the services - and it looks like the Air Force could be the service to watch closest as Ozturk (the General bearing the brunt of Erdogans accusations) so this service has a greater representation in the upper class in Turkey as evidenced by their boldness, they felt it necessary to support the constitution that Erdogan is destroying, to stand up a coup attempt. A mass execution of service members would quickly become a problem on the streets.

http://www.news.com.au/world/breaking-news/265-deaths-in-failed-turkey-coup/news-story/1111b2a30416fb70d83299cf505612f1 Human rights in Turkey are in peril following a bloody coup attempt on Friday 15 July, which resulted in the deaths of at least 208 people and almost 8,000 arrests, Amnesty International said today.
https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/07/turkey-human-rights-in-grave-danger-following-coup-attempt-and-subsequent-crackdown/

President Erdogan wants to transform Turkey to a presidential system. This necessitates changes to the constitution, which in turn requires a 3/5th majority in parliament.
When elections in June 2015 did not bring this majority, especially because the Kurdish HDP party entered parliament, Erdogan ended the peace process with the Kurdish PKK. Martial law and a media blackout in Kurdish areas followed, but reports of systematic destruction of HDP strongholds including the killing of hundreds of civilians still came to light. The repeat elections of November 2015 did not result in a 3/5th majority for Edogan, again, but the whole process demonstrates his willingness to sacrifice peace and hundreds of lives for his political aims and increased internal tensions and the societal polarization.
With Erdogans counter-coup and his Gleichschaltung of the judiciary, executive, media and education sector coupled with the removal of parliamentary immunity of more than a fourth of all parliamentarians, including 80% of the HDP representatives, Erdogan has everything in place to allow him to establish a totalitarian regime. Totalitarian regimes are historically prone to commit mass killings.
Edogans past use of force for political ends and his apparent lack of respect for human lives (for example illustrated by the debate about reintroducing the death penalty), combined his adventurism in foreign relations paint a picture of his character that makes it likely he could resort the use of deadly force against civilians on a grander scale.
As Turkey internal division between Kemalists and Islamists border on the edge of a civil war and a peaceful resolution is remote, the combined effects of Government purges and repression against opposition, the conflict with the PKK, terrorism from ISIS and civil strife between Kemalists and Islamists will most probably result in more than 1000 civilians being killed by armed forces, police or militias during this year.

(no change) First is EWP’s answer on the GJO questions: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/281886 One can either interpret it to mean the clock started when the question opened or try to parse this quote “over the course of the year, without regard to calendar year.” Second is the web page for the EWP expert opinion pool: http://www.earlywarningproject.com/opinion_pools (As you will note, the latter is for a calendar year. EWP tries to be clear that there are differences between the Expert Opinion Pool criteria and the GJO questions.) I’m updating my “understanding” so that I can find it easily and don’t have to guess: 1. The time frame for this episode starts on 25 May 2016 and ends 31 December 2016. (Please feel free to weigh in to explain the unexplainable.) 2. Official and unofficial violence against or by the main PKK (within Turkey) will not be considered as an on-going conflict. 3. Violence against Kurds cross-border in either Syria or Iraq will not be considered an episode of mass killing. 4. Violence against or by migrants or refugees in Turkey will count even though the proximate cause of their being in Turkey may be related to on-going conflicts elsewhere.

While Turkey will step security at home and aide in Iraq and Syria up following the attacks last week, ISIS will undoubtedly try to send the message to the rest of the world and potential recruits that despite the losses that they face in occupied areas, they are still present and only becoming more dangerous. They have recently amped up their foreign attacks, due in large to the mounting pressure that they feel from coalition forces in Iraq and Syria and will continue with this trend of solicited attacks around the world. I do not believe that it will be a straight forward attack, but a small group of like minded individuals (2-3); perhaps an independent group that pledges allegiance to the group. I also believe that there will be a string of suicide bombings in Istanbul and other Turkish towns.

As far as I can discern, blowing up random people at an airport does not meet the question's criterion, which requires the victims to be targeted as members of some specific group.  I don't like tourists any better than you do (if it's tourist season, why can't you shoot them?) but they seem ill-suited as a category for "mass killing" in this context.   And as a side note, I'm not sure you should count suicide bombers as "armed groups."  Their arms seem to come off pretty quickly for the most part.
Possible that Kurdish tensions boil over, but seems unlikely.

Initial forecast based on the active users views.

Per Google results for "Turkey, bombings, 2015", then same for 2016, there were 4 bombings in 2015, then 7 in the first 6 months of 2016.  The largest death toll was 100 (one attack, Ankara, Oct. 2015), and the rest caused considerably smaller numbers of dead.  There are a number of perpetrator groups: Islamic State, Kurdish groups and sub-groups, even a Marxist group. The Kurds state their general opposition to targeting civilians. The EWP defines "mass killing" as killing at least 1,000 civilians. So far the attacks have resulted in far too small numbers to suggest a significant number of future true mass attacks, but with so many perpetrator groups, there is some possibility of at least one real mass attack at some future time.

Reason is the extremely short time frame for this question. No clarification if violence against Kurds, and violence by terrorist groups does count. So staying low for now.

Any episode of mass killing will likely involve the Kurds. Given the year's half over, and while Turkey is becoming more authoritarian, I just don't see the threshold being met since the level of violence is too low.

Very informative link:  https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2016/country-chapters/turkey  List of killings by month:  http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/crisiswatch/crisiswatch-database.aspx?CountryIDs={5875B08E-4CDC-4879-9179-17AAE2724AEB} The Crisis Watch information is not as detailed as ACLED and I was not sure how to count some of the deaths.  What is clear is that a major escalation would have to occur to hit 1000.  It is possible with Turkey bombing in PKK areas and the actions of their security forces.  ISIS inflicted the single largest daily death toll of 102 in the October bombing, but the rate of the suicide bombings would have to increase dramatically.   A lot of suspected terrorists have been detained by the Turkish government, but I have not seen information about missing people or mass graves. Turkey has a number of political and social conditions that increase the potential for a mass killing to occur such as Erdogan’s consolidation of power, restrictions on the press, the large number of refugees, and the collapse of the PKK ceasefire.   This is one to watch but I am staying low for now.

Starting (imo) high with 15%, Turkey is a largely stable state -> low base rate. But the escalating Kurdish conflict pulls 1000 deaths/year in reach. Especially given the unclear definition of civilians (who will be the one deciding whether a dead person is a civilian or a terrorist?) and the use of airpower from the Turkish military (and therefore the possibility of a single attack with many casualties) produce quite a chance for crossing the EWP threshold.

had this one on the open 2016 thread (that we'd get a question) but at low probability Possible: 
- state vs Kurdish civilians
- civilian deaths from PKK?
- civilian deaths from ISIS?
- Syrians targeted (state?) Of these, killing of Kurdish civilians by state seems most probable to me. Some points of concern:  - media suppression - many journalists jailed or thrown out of the country.  Gov't take over of media outlets - seems to be a campaign of violence against Kurdish parts of the country - starts with declaration of curfew, followed by army moving in, bombing/destruction of homes and businesses, citizens not allowed access to medical care,  gov't says PKK but civilian deaths certainly too (children, pregnant women), followed by gov't bulldozing buildings and appropriating land.  Depopulation used as a tactic in previous Turkish-Kurdish conflict.  (one story: http://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/feb/09/destruction-sur-turkey-historic-district-gentrification-kurdish ) - constitutional amendment to move more power to president and away from parliament & prime minister - stripping immunity from prosecution from HDP members of parliament  - Erdogan's authoritarian personality, behavior Pro-Kurdish (and pro-journalist) bias in my media input - perhaps thanks to previous questions on Kurdish referendum, etc.  But looks bad and structural components seem to me to support potential for mass killing.  Some sources think 1000 civilians killed already. (http://www.aina.org/news/20160501130122.htm ) On the other hand,
- media suppression may result in lack of reporting - only state narrative known
- high bar, generally not likely to occur
- Turkey's position, need by EU, US for alliance, may result in under reporting
- difficulty knowing which deaths are civilian
- unsure how EWP will tally  Human Rights Watch: https://www.hrw.org/europe/central-asia/turkey
International Crisis Group: http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/regions/europe/turkey-cyprus/turkey.aspx

(down 1% so I can repost immediately) @EarlyWarningProject @GJDrew Some recommendations for structuring EWP questions. Within some format specifically include: 1. Start and stop (latter is normally present) time periods during which an "episode" will be counted. 2. Which if any existing categories of on-going conflicts (and/or the other possible categories) should be excluded from consideration (as it narrowly applies to the question). If there are none, please say so. 3. If there are grey/complicated issues (Kurds in Turkey are a great example) either try to provide guidance (e.g., violence against or by official PKK is regarded as a continuing conflict but splinter groups may or may not be included, and violence against Kurdish political entities such as . . . . would count toward the question) or explicitly explain why this will remain a hazy area that forecasters need to interpret the best they can. Thanks.

(no change) First of two posts mainly targeted at EWP. @EarlyWarningProject @GJDrew I really appreciate EWP providing guidance as best they can regarding this question and others. OTOH some of the feedback gets lost in the shuffle among different questions and buried in responses to older inquiries. I am 100% (sorry GJ ;-) certain that my following summary of what I think the EWP position is on this Kurdish question will be wrong, but perhaps you can use it as a start to help me: 1. The time frame for this episode is the whole calendar year 2016. 2. Official and unofficial violence against or by the main PKK (within Turkey) will not be considered as an on-going conflict. 3. Violence against Kurds cross-border in either Syria or Iraq will not be considered an episode of mass killing. 4. Violence against or by migrants or refugees in Turkey will count even though the proximate cause of their being in Turkey may be related to on-going conflicts elsewhere. Thanks.

It depends how we classify "mass-killing."  If we're talking about a bombing or other terrorist attack in a major Turkish city that kills dozens or hundreds of people, I think the chances are unfortunately considerable.  If we're talking about an organized massacre by either Turkish or militant (Kurdish, ISIS, whoever) forces, I think the chances are lower, but non-trivial.  There is also a possibility that there are mass protests somewhere in Turkey, and large numbers of protestors are killed by government crackdown, as has happened several times in Egypt in the past 5 years.
